title: Macro Tracking for People Who Hate Counting
excerpt: A lazy person's guide to getting your protein, carbs, and fats roughly right without losing your mind or your enjoyment of food.

body.text: I tried strict macro tracking for about three weeks before I wanted to throw my phone into a lake. Weighing every almond? Scanning every barcode? That's not sustainable when you're also packing lunches and negotiating with a 4-year-old about eating vegetables.
The 'Close Enough' Method

Here's what I actually do: I track roughly. I know what a palm-sized portion of protein looks like. I know a fist of carbs. A thumb of fat. Is it accurate to the gram? No. Is it accurate enough to make progress? Absolutely.
My Daily Targets (Roughly)

items: Protein: 150-180g (I aim for 40g per meal, 4 times a day)
Carbs: 200-250g (more on training days, less on rest days)
Fats: 60-70g (this usually takes care of itself)
Total: ~2,200 calories

body.text: The Staples That Make It Easy
I eat roughly the same things during the week. Not because I'm boring ‚Äî because decision fatigue is real when you have kids. Here are my go-tos:

items: Breakfast: Eggs + toast or protein shake + banana
Lunch: Chicken + rice bowl or turkey wrap
Dinner: Whatever the family eats (I just adjust my portion)
Snacks: Greek yogurt, protein bar, apple + almond butter

body.text: Weekends are more flexible. We eat out, we have pizza night, we live our lives. I don't track on weekends ‚Äî I just make generally smart choices and enjoy the time with family.
The One Non-Negotiable

If there's one thing I'd tell anyone to focus on, it's protein. Hit your protein target and everything else falls into place more easily. You're less hungry, you recover better, and you maintain muscle as you age. That's the whole game.

title: Working Out With a Toddler in the Room
excerpt: Yes, it's chaos. Yes, you'll get interrupted. Here's how to get a solid workout in anyway ‚Äî tiny humans included.

body.text: Let me paint you a picture: I'm mid-squat, barbell on my back, and my 3-year-old decides this is the perfect moment to show me her drawing. Of a cat. That needs a name. Right now.
If you're a parent who trains at home, you know exactly what I'm talking about. Here's how I've learned to make it work.
Accept the Chaos

Step one: let go of the idea of an uninterrupted 45-minute session. It's not happening. Once I accepted that, I actually started enjoying the absurdity of it. My daughter does 'squats' next to me with a pool noodle. My son counts my reps (inaccurately). It's messy and kind of perfect.
Strategies That Actually Help

items: Use rest periods for kid stuff ‚Äî answer the question, fix the snack, find the toy
Pick exercises that are safe to bail on (dumbbells > barbell when kids are around)
Set up a 'kid station' nearby with coloring books, blocks, or a tablet
Keep sessions short and intense ‚Äî 25 minutes of focus beats 60 minutes of distraction
Let them participate. Kid-sized dumbbells cost $10 and buy you infinite goodwill

body.text: The Real Lesson

Working out with your kids around isn't a limitation ‚Äî it's modeling behavior. They see you prioritizing your health. They see you pushing through something hard. They see you showing up even when it's not easy. That's a lesson no amount of talking can teach.

title: Zone 2 Cardio: The Boring Workout That Adds Years
excerpt: It doesn't look impressive. It won't get you likes. But zone 2 cardio might be the single best thing you can do for your health.

body.text: Zone 2 cardio is the most boring and most important type of exercise I do. It's not sexy. There's no before-and-after transformation. But the science behind it for longevity is overwhelming.
What Is Zone 2?

Zone 2 is the intensity where you can hold a conversation but it's slightly uncomfortable. You're breathing harder but you're not gasping. For most people, that's a brisk walk, an easy jog, or a moderate bike ride. Heart rate roughly 60-70% of your max.
Why It Matters

Zone 2 training improves your mitochondrial function ‚Äî basically, how efficiently your cells produce energy. It improves insulin sensitivity, cardiovascular health, and fat metabolism. Dr. Peter Attia calls it 'the most important exercise for longevity,' and after digging into the research, I agree.
How I Fit It In

items: 3-4 times per week, 30-45 minutes each
Usually a walk with the dog or a bike ride on the weekend
Sometimes I just walk on an incline treadmill while watching a show
I wear a cheap heart rate monitor to stay in the right zone

body.text: The beauty of zone 2 is that it doesn't beat you up. You can do it every day without affecting your recovery. It's the opposite of 'no pain, no gain' ‚Äî and it's arguably more important for your long-term health than any heavy lifting session.
The Dad Walk
My favorite zone 2 session? Walking the neighborhood with my kids on their bikes. They ride, I walk fast, we all get outside. Exercise that doubles as family time? That's the sweet spot.

title: The 5AM Garage Gym: How I Built a Routine That Actually Sticks
excerpt: Everyone talks about morning routines. Here's what mine actually looks like ‚Äî the good, the bad, and the days I hit snooze three times. How I went from zero consistency to never missing a weekday workout.

body.text: I'm not going to pretend I wake up every morning fired up and ready to crush a workout. Some days, the alarm goes off at 4:55 AM and every part of me wants to stay in bed. But I get up anyway. And that's kind of the whole point.
Why 5AM?

I didn't choose 5AM because I'm a morning person. I chose it because it's the only time that's truly mine. By 6:30, the kids are up. By 7:15, we're in full breakfast-backpack-bus-stop chaos. If I don't train before the house wakes up, it's not happening.
The garage gym helps too. No commute to a gym means I roll out of bed, throw on shorts, and I'm already there. The barrier to entry is literally just standing up.
The Actual Routine
I keep it simple. Four days a week, alternating between upper and lower body. Each session is 35-45 minutes. Here's what a typical week looks like:

items: Monday: Upper body (push focus) ‚Äî bench press, overhead press, rows, curls
Tuesday: Lower body ‚Äî squats, Romanian deadlifts, lunges, calf raises
Thursday: Upper body (pull focus) ‚Äî pull-ups, dumbbell rows, face pulls, triceps
Friday: Lower body + conditioning ‚Äî deadlifts, leg press, kettlebell swings

body.text: Wednesday is a rest day or a light walk. Weekends are for family hikes, backyard play, or just resting. No guilt.
What Made It Stick
Three things changed everything for me:

items: I stopped chasing perfection. A 20-minute session beats a skipped one.
I laid out my clothes the night before. Removes one more decision.
I tracked consistency, not weight. My goal is 4 sessions per week, not a PR.

body.text: The first two weeks were brutal. But after that, it became automatic. Now it feels weird NOT to train in the morning.
The Honest Truth

I still have bad days. Last week I slept through my alarm twice. The week before, my kid was sick and I was up all night. Life happens. The difference is I don't let one missed day turn into a missed week anymore.
If you're thinking about starting a morning routine ‚Äî start smaller than you think. Even 15 minutes. The habit of showing up matters more than the workout itself.

title: Why "Good Enough" Is the Goal
excerpt: Perfectionism is the enemy of consistency. Here's why I stopped chasing optimal and started chasing sustainable ‚Äî and got better results.

body.text: For years, I'd start a fitness plan, go all-in for two or three weeks, and then crash. The plan was always too perfect ‚Äî 6 workouts a week, meal prep every Sunday, no cheat meals, sleep by 10 PM. Real life doesn't work like that.
The Shift

The turning point came when I lowered my standards. Not in a giving-up way ‚Äî in a realistic way. Instead of 6 workouts, I aimed for 3. Instead of perfect nutrition, I aimed for 'mostly good.' Instead of no junk food, I aimed for 80/20.
And something unexpected happened: I actually stuck with it. For the first time in years, I was consistent. And consistency beat intensity every single time.
The Math of 'Good Enough'

items: Perfect plan followed for 3 weeks = 18 workouts, then 0
Good enough plan followed for 12 months = 150+ workouts
Guess which one gets better results?

body.text: What 'Good Enough' Looks Like

For me, good enough means: train 3-4 times a week, eat mostly whole foods, get 7+ hours of sleep most nights, walk daily, and don't stress the rest. Some weeks are better than others. That's fine. The trend line is what matters, not any single day.
Give yourself permission to be imperfect. It's the most productive thing you'll ever do for your health.

title: The Only 5 Exercises You Actually Need
excerpt: Forget the complicated routines. If you can do these five movements consistently, you're ahead of 90% of the population.

body.text: The fitness industry wants you to think you need 47 different exercises, a periodized program, and a PhD in kinesiology. You don't. If you're a parent just trying to stay healthy and functional, here are the only five movements that matter.
1. Squat

Barbell, goblet, bodyweight ‚Äî doesn't matter. Squatting keeps your legs strong, your knees healthy, and your ability to get off the floor intact as you age. I do goblet squats with a dumbbell 2x per week. Nothing fancy.
2. Hinge (Deadlift)

Picking heavy stuff off the ground. This builds your back, glutes, and hamstrings ‚Äî the muscles that protect your spine when you're lifting kids, groceries, or furniture. Romanian deadlifts with dumbbells are my go-to.
3. Push (Bench Press / Push-Ups)
Upper body pushing. Bench press, push-ups, overhead press ‚Äî pick one or rotate. This keeps your chest, shoulders, and arms strong for carrying kids, pushing strollers, and everyday life.
4. Pull (Rows / Pull-Ups)
The counterbalance to all that pushing (and all that sitting at a desk). Rows and pull-ups build the back muscles that keep your posture solid. I do dumbbell rows every upper body day.
5. Carry (Farmer's Walk)

Grab two heavy dumbbells and walk. That's it. This builds grip strength, core stability, and total body endurance. It's also the most 'real life' exercise there is ‚Äî when was the last time you carried a sleeping child plus three bags of groceries up the stairs?
The Bottom Line

Master these five movements and you're set. You don't need fancy equipment, a gym membership, or a complicated program. Just these five, done consistently, with gradual progress. That's the whole recipe.

title: Meal Prep Sunday: A Real Parent's Version
excerpt: I've got about 90 minutes on Sunday afternoon. Here's how I prep meals for the week that the whole family will actually eat.

body.text: Every meal prep guide I've seen assumes you have 4 hours, 30 containers, and zero children. Here's my version ‚Äî the one that actually works when you've got a 90-minute window while the kids are doing quiet time.
The 90-Minute Game Plan
I don't prep every meal for the week. I prep the things that, if I don't have ready, will lead me to order takeout. That means: protein, grains, and a few snacks.
What I Actually Prep

items: 2 lbs chicken breast ‚Äî seasoned and baked (used in bowls, wraps, salads all week)
A big pot of rice or quinoa
Cut vegetables ‚Äî peppers, cucumbers, cherry tomatoes
Hard-boiled eggs (a dozen)
Overnight oats for 3 mornings (oats, protein powder, milk, chia seeds in jars)

body.text: The Family Crossover

Here's the trick: most of what I prep works for the whole family. The chicken goes into the kids' quesadillas. The rice goes with their dinner. I'm not making two separate meals ‚Äî I'm making building blocks that everyone can use differently.

Dinners are still cooked fresh most nights ‚Äî usually something simple like sheet pan chicken and veggies, turkey tacos, or pasta. The prep just handles lunches and breakfasts so I'm not scrambling every morning.
My Advice

Don't try to be a meal prep influencer. You don't need 15 matching containers and a color-coded menu. Just cook some protein, cook some carbs, and cut some vegetables. That's 80% of the battle right there.
